Fagel Stern Papers
Stern, Fagel, 1904-1936
Stern, Phyllis
TAM.091
0.25 Linear Feet in one manuscript box.
1922-1983 Faygle Stern (circa 1904-1936) was a Polish Jewish communist active in the Jewish Section of the International Workers Order in New York. She came to the United States in 1921, and died in childbirth in January, 1936. The collection includes her diary, correspondence with her brother Abram Judah, a communist who lived in Havana and the USSR, and biographical material (reminiscence, sketch, obituary). The diary, notebooks, and most of the letters are in Yiddish. The diary, notebooks, and most of the letters are in Yiddish. The rest of the collection is in English.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Phyllis Stern (niece of Fagel Stern), 1990. The accession numbers associated with this gift are 1990.005 and 1990.008.
Historical/Biographical Note
Faygle Stern (circa 1904-1936), was a Jewish communist active in the Jewish Section of the International Workers Order, primarily as a teacher in the Yiddish shule movement in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, New York. She was born in Ostroleka (a.k.a. Ostrolenka), Poland, came to the United States in 1921, and died in childbirth in January, 1936.
Scope and Content Note
This collection contains Stern's diary; two notebooks with comments on Jews, Zionism, and world affairs; correspondence from family members, friends, and colleagues; and photographs. The collection also contains biographical material.
Existence and Location of Copies
Box 1 of this collection are photocopies of the original materials in Box 2.
Processing Information
Photographs were separated from this collection during initial processing and were established as a separate collection, the Fagel Stern Photographs (PHOTOS 177). In 2013, the photograph collection was reincorporated into the Fagel Stern Papers.
Arrangement
Folders are arranged alphabetically by subject/author.
The files are grouped into two series:
Series I: Papers
Series II: Photographs
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Due to the fragile nature of the original materials, researchers must use the access photocopies in Box 1.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Conditions Governing Use
The Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Archives has no information about copyright ownership for this collection and is not authorized to grant permission to publish or reproduce materials from it. Materials in this collection, which were created in 1922-1983, are expected to enter the public domain in 2104.

Scope and Content Note
This series contains Stern's diary, maintained during her fatal pregnancy, in which personal and political concerns are co-mingled. The series also contains her political notebooks; letters from her brother Abram Judah, also a communist who lived in Havana before returning to the USSR, where he died in 1933; letters from her brother Beryl, who came to the U.S. from Ostrolenka in 1935, and letters from her brother Chiel, who remained in Poland.
